newsitem.title: JAPAN: Airbus unlikely to reconsider business with Rolls.
newsitem.headline: Airbus unlikely to reconsider business with Rolls.

text.p: Airbus Industrie is not likely to reconsider its business dealings with Rolls-Royce Plc despite recent problems with Rolls-Royce jet engines on Airbus aircraft, said Adam Brown, an Airbus vice president in charge of market forecasts.

Hong Kong's two airlines suspended a total of 15 Airbus Industrie A330-300 aircraft on Saturday, leading to the cancellation of 23 flights, due to concerns about the reliability of their Rolls-Royce Trent 700 engines.
A Hong Kong Dragon Airlines Ltd A330 made an emergency landing on Friday on one of its two engines at Subic Bay in the Philippines after developing engine trouble.
It was the latest in a series of single-engine landings by Dragonair and Cathay Pacific Airways Ltd Airbus A330-300 planes.
"We're very sympathetic to the problem that Cathay Pacific had," Adams told a news conference on Tuesday.

He said Airbus offers a choice of jet engines from Rolls-Royce, General Electric and United Technologies Corp unit Pratt & Whitney, and it is up to the individual airlines to select the engine they want.
Asked if Airbus would reconsider doing business with Rolls-Royce as a result of the two Hong Kong airlines' problems, Adams said that the possibility of such a reconsideration was slight.
He also stressed that Rolls-Royce, like Airbus, was a European company, and that political polarisation was a factor in the global airline and aircraft industries.
"We must recognise the fact that Rolls-Royce is a European company," he said.
